**Martin Van Buren** (born **Maarten van Buren** ; December 5, 1782 – July 24,
1862) was an American statesman who served as the
[eighth](/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States "List of Presidents of
the United States") [President of the United
States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States")
from 1837 to 1841. A founder of the [Democratic
Party](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_Democratic_Party "History of the
United States Democratic Party"), he held a number of senior positions in the
[U.S. Federal Government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States
"Federal government of the United States"), including
[eighth](/wiki/List_of_Vice_Presidents_of_the_United_States "List of Vice
Presidents of the United States") [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States") (1833–1837) and
[tenth](/wiki/List_of_Secretaries_of_State_of_the_United_States "List of
Secretaries of State of the United States") [Secretary of
State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States Secretary of
State") (1829–1831), both under [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew
Jackson"). Van Buren won the presidency by promising to continue Jackson's
policies. The [Panic of 1837](/wiki/Panic_of_1837 "Panic of 1837") which
struck the nation combined with the growing political strength of the
opposition [Whig Party](/wiki/Whig_Party_\(United_States\) "Whig Party
\(United States\)") led to his defeat when he ran for reelection. During his
half-century of public service, he built and perfected a new system of
political parties at first the [state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") and then
the [federal](/wiki/United_States_federal_government "United States federal
government") level; at the end of his life, he was seen as a major figure of
the [abolitionist movement](/wiki/Abolitionism "Abolitionism") defending
[Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln")'s policies during
the American Civil War. Van Buren was the first President of the United States
to be born a [United States citizen](/wiki/Natural-born-citizen_clause
"Natural-born-citizen clause").[4] Of [Dutch descent](/wiki/Dutch_Americans
"Dutch Americans"), he is the only U.S. President who spoke [English as a
second language](/wiki/English_as_a_second_or_foreign_language "English as a
second or foreign language").

A delegate to a political convention at age 18, he quickly moved from local to
state politics, gaining fame both as a political organizer and an accomplished
lawyer. Elected to the U.S. Senate by the [New York State
Legislature](/wiki/New_York_State_Legislature "New York State Legislature") in
1821, he reorganized the [Democratic-Republican Party](/wiki/Democratic-
Republican_Party "Democratic-Republican Party") in [New
York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)") and established the
[Albany Regency](/wiki/Albany_Regency "Albany Regency") to keep it in power.
Van Buren supported [William H. Crawford](/wiki/William_H._Crawford "William
H. Crawford") for President in the [1824
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1824 "United States
presidential election, 1824"). [John Quincy Adams](/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams
"John Quincy Adams") was then made president in a [contingent
election](/wiki/Contingent_election "Contingent election"). The supporters of
Jackson, who had won a plurality of the popular and electoral vote, coalesced
around Jackson to create the new Democratic Party. Van Buren, alarmed by the
nationalist policies of the Adams administration, soon joined them. Van Buren
was a major supporter and organizer for Jackson in the [1828
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1828 "United States
presidential election, 1828"), and ran for [Governor of New
York](/wiki/Governor_of_New_York "Governor of New York") in the hope of using
his personal popularity to boost Jackson's campaign. Jackson and Van Buren
were elected, and after serving as governor for two months, Van Buren resigned
to become Jackson's [Secretary of
State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States Secretary of
State"). During Jackson's eight years as President, Van Buren was a key
advisor, and built the organizational structure for the coalescing Democratic
Party, particularly in New York. He resigned as Secretary of State in 1831 to
help resolve the [Petticoat affair](/wiki/Petticoat_affair "Petticoat
affair"). Jackson gave Van Buren a [recess
appointment](/wiki/Recess_appointment "Recess appointment") as [American
Minister to Britain](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_the_United_Kingdom
"United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom"). Van Buren's nomination was
rejected by the Senate, cutting short his service in London, but he was
elected Vice President in the [1832
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1832 "United States
presidential election, 1832").

With Jackson's strong support, Van Buren faced little opposition for the
presidential nomination at the [1835 Democratic National
Convention](/wiki/1835_Democratic_National_Convention "1835 Democratic
National Convention"), and he defeated several Whig opponents in the [1836
presidential election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1836 "United
States presidential election, 1836"). As President, Van Buren was blamed for
the depression of 1837; hostile newspapers called him "Martin Van Ruin". He
attempted to cure the economic problems by keeping control of federal funds in
an [independent treasury](/wiki/Independent_Treasury "Independent Treasury"),
rather than in state banks, but Congress would not approve of this until 1840.
In foreign affairs, he denied the application of [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas")
for admission to the Union, unwilling to upset the balance of free and slave
states in the [Missouri Compromise](/wiki/Missouri_Compromise "Missouri
Compromise"), and hoping to avoid war with Mexico over [Texas
annexation](/wiki/Texas_annexation "Texas annexation"). Additionally,
relations with Britain and its colonies in [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada")
proved to be strained from the bloodless [Aroostook War](/wiki/Aroostook_War
"Aroostook War") and the [_Caroline_ Affair](/wiki/Caroline_affair "Caroline
affair"). In the [1840
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1840 "United States
presidential election, 1840"), Van Buren was voted out of office, losing to
Whig candidate [William Henry Harrison](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison "William
Henry Harrison").

Van Buren was the leading candidate for the [Democratic nomination in
1844](/wiki/1844_Democratic_National_Convention "1844 Democratic National
Convention"), but his continued opposition to the annexation of Texas caused
him to lose to [James K. Polk](/wiki/James_K._Polk "James K. Polk"), who [went
on to win the election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1844
"United States presidential election, 1844"). In the [1848
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1848 "United States
presidential election, 1848"), Van Buren ran unsuccessfully as the candidate
of the anti-slavery [Free Soil Party](/wiki/Free_Soil_Party "Free Soil
Party"). He returned to the Democratic fold to endorse [Franklin
Pierce](/wiki/Franklin_Pierce "Franklin Pierce") (1852), [James
Buchanan](/wiki/James_Buchanan "James Buchanan") (1856), and [Stephen A.
Douglas](/wiki/Stephen_A._Douglas "Stephen A. Douglas") (1860) for the
presidency. His increasingly [abolitionist](/wiki/Abolitionism "Abolitionism")
views and support for the [Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union
\(American Civil War\)") led him to support [Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") after the start of the
American Civil War. Van Buren's health began to fail in 1861, and he died in
July 1862 at age 79. He has been [generally
ranked](/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States
"Historical rankings of presidents of the United States") as a below-average
president.

## Early life and
education[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life and education")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Martin_Van_Buren_Baptism_record.jpg/170px-
Martin_Van_Buren_Baptism_record.jpg)](/wiki/File:Martin_Van_Buren_Baptism_record.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Martin_Van_Buren_Baptism_record.jpg "Enlarge")

Record of [Kinderhook Dutch Reformed
Church](/wiki/Kinderhook_Dutch_Reformed_Church "Kinderhook Dutch Reformed
Church") "Maarten" Van Buren (Dutch sp.) baptism December 15, 1782

Martin Van Buren was born on December 5, 1782, in the village of [Kinderhook,
New York](/wiki/Kinderhook_\(village\),_New_York "Kinderhook \(village\), New
York") about 20 miles (32 km) south of [Albany](/wiki/Albany,_New_York
"Albany, New York") on the [Hudson River](/wiki/Hudson_River "Hudson River").
He was the first President not born a [British subject](/wiki/British_subject
"British subject"), or even of [British ancestry](/wiki/British_ancestry
"British ancestry").[2] He was a descendant of Cornelis Maessen of the village
of [Buurmalsen](/wiki/Buurmalsen "Buurmalsen"), near the town of
[Buren](/wiki/Buren "Buren") in the Netherlands, who had come to North America
in 1631 and had purchased a plot of land on Manhattan Island; his son Martin
Cornelisen took the surname Van Buren.[5][6] His father, Abraham Van Buren
(1737–1817), owned and operated an inn and tavern, and Martin was born in a
house that was attached to the tavern.[7][8][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] Abraham Van Buren supported the [Patriot
cause](/wiki/Patriot_\(American_Revolution\) "Patriot \(American
Revolution\)") during the [American Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution
"American Revolution") as a [captain](/wiki/Captain_\(United_States_O-3\)
"Captain \(United States O-3\)") in the [Albany County Militia's 7th
Regiment](/wiki/Van_Alstyne%27s_Regiment_of_Militia "Van Alstyne's Regiment of
Militia"),[9][10] and later joined the [Jeffersonian
Republicans](/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Party "Democratic-Republican
Party").[11] He was active in local politics and government, and served as
Kinderhook's town clerk from 1787 to 1797.[12] In 1776, Abraham Van Buren
married Maria Hoes (or Goes) Van Alen (1747–1818), the widow of Johannes Van
Alen.

Although both Abraham and Maria Van Buren were fifth generation residents of
the [Province of New York](/wiki/Province_of_New_York "Province of New York"),
all of their forebears were of Dutch ancestry, as was the case for most of
Kinderhook's residents, and they still spoke [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language
"Dutch language") as their [first language](/wiki/First_language "First
language"). The future president was [baptized](/wiki/Baptized "Baptized") on
December 15, 1782, as "Maarten Van Buren", the original Dutch spelling of his
name. He had four full siblings and three half-siblings.  
From his mother's first marriage:

  * Marytje (or Maria) Van Alen (1768–1829), married John L. Hoes.[13][14]
  * John I. Van Alen (1770–1805)[15][16]
  * [James I. Van Alen](/wiki/James_I._Van_Alen "James I. Van Alen") (1772-1822), who practiced law with Van Buren for a time and also served as a member of Congress (1807–1809).

From his parents' marriage:[17][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_][18]

  * Dirckie "Derike" Van Buren (1777–1865), married Barent Hoes (1777–1853). Barent Hoes was the brother of Martin Van Buren's wife, and served in local offices including town clerk.[19][20][21]
  * Jannetje (Called "Hannah" or "Jane") Van Buren (1780–1838), who never married and who resided with her sister Dirckie Van Buren and brother-in-law Barent Hoes.[22]
  * Lawrence Van Buren (1786–1868), a store owner and attorney who served as a militia officer in the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812") and held local offices including Kinderhook [Town Supervisor](/wiki/Town_Supervisor "Town Supervisor"), postmaster, and presidential elector [in 1852](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1852 "United States presidential election, 1852").[23]
  * Abraham Van Buren (1788–1836), an attorney who served as Columbia County Surrogate after Martin Van Buren and James I. Van Alen.[24][25]

Van Buren received a basic education at the village schoolhouse and briefly
studied [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") at the [Kinderhook
Academy](/wiki/Kinderhook_Academy "Kinderhook Academy") and at [Washington
Seminary](/wiki/Washington_Seminary "Washington Seminary") in
Claverack.[26][27] His formal education ended in 1796, when he began [reading
law](/wiki/Reading_law "Reading law") at the office of [Peter
Silvester](/wiki/Peter_Silvester_\(1734%E2%80%931808\) "Peter Silvester
\(1734–1808\)") and his son Francis, prominent
[Federalist](/wiki/Federalist_Party "Federalist Party") attorneys in
Kinderhook.[28] Van Buren learned early to interact with people from varied
ethnic, income, and societal groups, which he would later use to his advantage
as a political organizer.[29]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Hannah_van_buren_2.jpg/170px-
Hannah_van_buren_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hannah_van_buren_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hannah_van_buren_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Hannah Van Buren

He was small in stature; as an adult he was 5 feet 6 inches tall, and was
often referred to as "Little Van."[30] When he first began his legal studies,
he often presented an unkempt appearance in rough, homespun clothing.[31] The
Silvesters admonished Van Buren about how crucial a lawyer's clothing and
personal appearance were to the success of his practice. He accepted their
advice and patterned his clothing, appearance, bearing and conduct after
theirs.[32][33] After six years under the Silvesters, the elder Silvester and
Democratic-Republican political figure [John Peter Van
Ness](/wiki/John_Peter_Van_Ness "John Peter Van Ness") suggested that Van
Buren's political leanings constrained him to complete his education with a
Democratic-Republican attorney. Accepting this advice, he spent a final year
of apprenticeship in the [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City")
office of John Van Ness's brother [William P. Van
Ness](/wiki/William_P._Van_Ness "William P. Van Ness"), a political lieutenant
of [Aaron Burr](/wiki/Aaron_Burr "Aaron Burr").[34] Van Buren was
[admitted](/wiki/Admission_to_practice_law "Admission to practice law") to the
New York bar in 1803.[35][36]

Van Buren married [Hannah Hoes](/wiki/Hannah_Van_Buren "Hannah Van Buren"),
his childhood sweetheart and a daughter of his first cousin, on February 21,
1807, in [Catskill, New York](/wiki/Catskill,_New_York "Catskill, New
York").[37] Like Van Buren, she was raised in a Dutch home; she spoke
primarily Dutch, and spoke English with a distinct accent.[38] The couple had
five sons:[2][3]

  * [Abraham](/wiki/Abraham_Van_Buren "Abraham Van Buren") (1807–1873) a graduate of West Point and career military officer
  * [John](/wiki/John_Van_Buren "John Van Buren") (1810–1866), graduate of Yale and Attorney General of New York
  * Martin, Jr. (1812–1855), secretary to his father and editor of his father's papers until a premature death from tuberculosis
  * Winfield Scott (born and died in 1814)
  * Smith Thompson (1817–1876), an editor and special assistant to his father during Van Buren's presidency.

After 12 years of marriage, Hannah Van Buren contracted
[tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis "Tuberculosis") and died on February 5,
1819, at the age of 35.[39] Martin Van Buren never remarried.[40]

## Early political
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Early political career")]

Van Buren had been active in politics from age 18 if not before; he attended a
[Democratic-Republican Party](/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Party "Democratic-
Republican Party") convention in [Troy, New York](/wiki/Troy,_New_York "Troy,
New York") where he worked successfully to secure for [John Peter Van
Ness](/wiki/John_Peter_Van_Ness "John Peter Van Ness") the party nomination in
a special election for the [6th Congressional
District](/wiki/New_York%27s_6th_congressional_district "New York's 6th
congressional district") seat.[41] He formed a law partnership with his half-
brother [James I. Van Alen](/wiki/James_I._Van_Alen "James I. Van Alen") and
became financially secure enough to increase his focus on politics.[42] He was
a supporter of [Aaron Burr](/wiki/Aaron_Burr "Aaron Burr"), and allied himself
with the [George Clinton faction](/wiki/George_Clinton_\(vice_president\)
"George Clinton \(vice president\)") of the [Democratic-Republican
Party](/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Party "Democratic-Republican Party"). Van
Buren supported [Daniel D. Tompkins](/wiki/Daniel_D._Tompkins "Daniel D.
Tompkins") for Governor over incumbent [Morgan
Lewis](/wiki/Morgan_Lewis_\(governor\) "Morgan Lewis \(governor\)") in 1807.
Tompkins won, and his allies won a majority in the state legislature. As a
result, Van Buren was appointed [Surrogate](/wiki/Probate_court "Probate
court") of [Columbia County, New York](/wiki/Columbia_County,_New_York
"Columbia County, New York"), replacing Van Alen, who had supported Lewis. He
served as Surrogate from 1808 until 1813, when the [Federalist
Party](/wiki/Federalist_Party "Federalist Party") gained a majority in the
state legislature and replaced him.[43][44]

Van Buren was a member of the [New York State
Senate](/wiki/New_York_State_Senate "New York State Senate") from 1813 to
1820, and in 1813 joined the [opposition party](/wiki/Bucktails
"Bucktails")—New York Democratic-Republicans who fought [DeWitt
Clinton](/wiki/DeWitt_Clinton "DeWitt Clinton") for control of that party in
New York. Van Buren served as [New York Attorney
General](/wiki/New_York_Attorney_General "New York Attorney General") from
1815 to 1819. He replaced [William Floyd](/wiki/William_Floyd "William Floyd")
as a [presidential elector](/wiki/Presidential_elector "Presidential elector")
in [1820](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1820 "United States
presidential election, 1820"), and voted for [James Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe
"James Monroe") and [Daniel D. Tompkins](/wiki/Daniel_D._Tompkins "Daniel D.
Tompkins").[45]

Though he never served in the military, during the [War of
1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812") Van Buren worked in the State Senate to
pass war measures, including bills to expand the [New York
Militia](/wiki/New_York_Army_National_Guard "New York Army National Guard")
and increase soldier pay. In addition, he was a special judge advocate
appointed to serve as a prosecutor of [William Hull](/wiki/William_Hull
"William Hull") during Hull's court-martial following the surrender of
[Detroit](/wiki/Detroit,_Michigan "Detroit, Michigan").[46][47] In the winter
of 1814–15 he collaborated with [Winfield Scott](/wiki/Winfield_Scott
"Winfield Scott") on ways to reorganize the New York Militia in anticipation
of another military campaign in 1815. The reorganization would have included a
position for Van Buren at a rank to be determined, but the war's end in
February 1815 ended their work on the project.[48]

He initially opposed DeWitt Clinton's plan for the [Erie
Canal](/wiki/Erie_Canal "Erie Canal"), but relented when the
[Bucktails](/wiki/Bucktails "Bucktails"), the anti-DeWitt Clinton Democratic-
Republicans, were able to gain a majority on the [Erie Canal
Commission](/wiki/Erie_Canal_Commission "Erie Canal Commission"); he supported
a bill to finance its construction through the sale of state bonds.[49]

From 1816 to 1829, Van Buren served as a member of the [University of the
State of New York](/wiki/University_of_the_State_of_New_York "University of
the State of New York") Board of Regents.[50] In 1817, Van Buren's connection
with so-called "machine politics" started when he created the first political
organization encompassing all of New York, the Bucktails.[51] The Bucktails
succeeded in emphasizing party loyalty and used it to capture and control many
patronage posts throughout New York. Van Buren gained the nickname of "Little
Magician" for the skill with which he exploited the "[spoils
system](/wiki/Spoils_system "Spoils system")". He was a member of the 1820
state [constitutional
convention](/wiki/Constitutional_convention_\(political_meeting\)
"Constitutional convention \(political meeting\)"), where he favored expanded
voting rights, but opposed universal suffrage and tried to maintain property
requirements for voting.[52]

He was the leading figure in the [Albany Regency](/wiki/Albany_Regency "Albany
Regency"), a group of Bucktail leaders who for more than a generation
dominated New York politics and influenced national politics. The Regency,
together with other political organizations such as [Tammany
Hall](/wiki/Tammany_Hall "Tammany Hall"), played a major role in expanding the
spoils system and making it a recognized and accepted procedure. While
organizing and overseeing the operations of the Regency, Van Buren resided in
[Albany](/wiki/Albany,_New_York "Albany, New York"); his housemate was [Roger
Skinner](/wiki/Roger_Skinner "Roger Skinner"), a lifelong bachelor who was
also a key Van Buren lieutenant in the State Senate and as Judge of the
[United States District Court for the Northern District of New
York](/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Northern_District_of_New_York
"United States District Court for the Northern District of New York").[53] Van
Buren was the prime architect of the first nationwide political party: the
[Jacksonian Democrats](/wiki/Jacksonian_Democrats "Jacksonian Democrats") or
[Democratic Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)"), which evolved from the Democratic-Republicans and relied
on party loyalty and patronage to prevent contentious sectional issues,
including tariffs and slavery, from becoming national crises. In Van Buren's
words, "Without strong national political organizations, there would be
nothing to moderate the prejudices between free and slaveholding states."[54]
As had [James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison") and other
Democratic Party organizers who favored [states'
rights](/wiki/States%27_rights "States' rights") and local control, Van Buren
was struggling to find an institutional solution to the Constitution's seeming
inability to prevent concentration of power in an [administrative
republic](/wiki/Administrative_republic "Administrative republic").[55]

Early in his life Van Buren owned a slave, a man named Tom who served as his
personal valet. Tom ran away in 1814 and eventually settled in
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"), with Van Buren making no effort to locate
him. In 1824 Tom was found to be living in [Worcester,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Worcester,_Massachusetts "Worcester, Massachusetts").
Since he still legally owned Tom (under New York's gradual emancipation law,
slavery was scheduled to be completely abolished in the state in 1827), Van
Buren privately agreed to sell Tom to the finder for $50, provided the finder,
a resident of [Rensselaer County](/wiki/Rensselaer_County,_New_York
"Rensselaer County, New York"), could guarantee that Tom would be captured
without violence. He could not make such a guarantee, and his willingness to
pay was lessened by the knowledge that Tom would be emancipated in fewer than
three years even if he was re-enslaved, so Tom remained free, as Van Buren
probably intended. (Allowing Tom to remain in Massachusetts unmolested without
notice enabled Van Buren to avoid offending southern slave owners, as he would
do if he publicly allowed a former slave to remain free. At the same time, he
avoided offending northern abolitionists, which he would do if he captured and
re-enslaved a former slave.)[56][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_][57]

### U.S. Senate and national
politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: U.S. Senate and national politics")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/MVanBuren.png/260px-
MVanBuren.png)](/wiki/File:MVanBuren.png)

[](/wiki/File:MVanBuren.png "Enlarge")

Gubernatorial [portrait](/wiki/Portrait "Portrait") of Martin Van Buren by
[Daniel Huntington](/wiki/Daniel_Huntington_\(artist\) "Daniel Huntington
\(artist\)")

In [February 1821](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_New_York,_1821
"United States Senate election in New York, 1821") Van Buren was elected a
[U.S. Senator from New York](/wiki/U.S._Senator_from_New_York "U.S. Senator
from New York"), defeating incumbent [Nathan Sanford](/wiki/Nathan_Sanford
"Nathan Sanford"), who ran as the [Clintonian](/wiki/DeWitt_Clinton "DeWitt
Clinton") candidate.[58] Van Buren initially favored [internal
improvements](/wiki/Internal_improvements "Internal improvements"), such as
road repairs and canal construction; he proposed a constitutional amendment in
1824 to authorize such undertakings, but changed his position the following
year. He voted for the [tariffs](/wiki/Tariff_in_American_history "Tariff in
American history") of 1824 and 1828, and then gradually abandoned this
protectionist position, later supporting tariffs "for revenue only."[59]

In the [presidential election of
1824](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1824 "United States
presidential election, 1824"), Van Buren supported the nominee of a
Congressional caucus, Treasury Secretary [William H.
Crawford](/wiki/William_H._Crawford "William H. Crawford"), and received the
electoral votes of [Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_\(U.S._state\) "Georgia \(U.S.
state\)") for [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States_of_America "Vice
President of the United States of America"). None of the presidential
candidates—Crawford, [John Quincy Adams](/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams "John Quincy
Adams"), [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson"), or [Henry
Clay](/wiki/Henry_Clay "Henry Clay")—had received a majority of the electoral
college votes, so [the choice
fell](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1824#1825_Contingent_election
"United States presidential election, 1824") to the [United States House of
Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives"). The House had to choose from among the top three
candidates, so Clay was eliminated. Van Buren had originally hoped to block
[John Quincy Adams](/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams "John Quincy Adams") by denying
him the state of New York, which was divided between supporters of Crawford
and Adams. However, Representative [Stephen Van
Rensselaer](/wiki/Stephen_Van_Rensselaer "Stephen Van Rensselaer") swung New
York to Adams. Adams won, and appointed Clay as Secretary of State. Because
Clay had supported Adams in the House election, Jackson and Crawford
supporters alleged corruption.[60] After the House contest, Van Buren shrewdly
kept out of [the controversy which
followed](/wiki/Corrupt_Bargain#Election_of_1824 "Corrupt Bargain"), and began
looking forward to 1828. He switched his support early from Crawford, whose
ill health after a stroke had made him a less than viable candidate, to
[Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson"), who had won the
popular vote in 1824. Jackson was angered to see the presidency go to Adams
after he received fewer popular votes, and eagerly looked forward to a
rematch.[61]

Always notably courteous in his treatment of opponents, Van Buren showed no
bitterness toward either Adams or [Henry Clay](/wiki/Henry_Clay "Henry Clay"),
and he voted for Clay's confirmation as [Secretary of
State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States Secretary of
State"), notwithstanding Jackson's "[corrupt bargain](/wiki/Corrupt_bargain
"Corrupt bargain")" charge.[62][63] At the same time, he opposed the Adams-
Clay plans for internal infrastructure improvements (roads, canals, bridges,
etc.) and declined to support U.S. participation in the [Congress of
Panama](/wiki/Congress_of_Panama "Congress of Panama").[64] As chair of the
Judiciary Committee, he brought forward a number of measures for the
improvement of judicial procedure, including one (not adopted), which would
have required a super-majority vote by the [United States Supreme
Court](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court "United States Supreme Court") to
declare a law unconstitutional.[65] In May 1826, Van Buren joined with Senator
[Thomas Hart Benton](/wiki/Thomas_Hart_Benton_\(senator\) "Thomas Hart Benton
\(senator\)") in reporting on patronage in the executive branch, going against
his own use of the spoils system to propose, in vain, that Presidents not be
able to remove officeholders at will, and that Presidents report to Congress
on the reason for dismissal of federal position holders.[66] The 1828 "[Tariff
of Abominations](/wiki/Tariff_of_1828 "Tariff of 1828")" was recognized as his
work. Since Democrats, especially Southerners, were generally opposed to
tariffs that increased the price of manufactured goods from the North but did
not benefit the raw materials produced in the South, Van Buren could normally
have been expected to oppose tariffs. Political observers of the time viewed
Van Buren's efforts to pass the 1828 tariff as part of the campaign to elect
Jackson as President. Anticipating that most Southerners would vote for Andrew
Jackson no matter who else was running, Van Buren intended the tariff proposed
by Jackson's Northern Democratic supporters in Congress to attract to
Jackson's candidacy Northern voters, who generally favored high tariffs to
protect the manufactured goods they produced. Van Buren voted in favor, later
adopting the cover story that he had done so only in response to instructions
from the [New York State Legislature](/wiki/New_York_State_Legislature "New
York State Legislature"). Most Democrats, especially Southerners, continued to
oppose tariffs after 1828. Van Buren's political opponents in the Democratic
Party used his 1828 vote against him for years afterwards to prevent him from
obtaining Southern support for his candidacies.[67][68][69]

Van Buren was not an exceptional orator like Henry Clay or [Daniel
Webster](/wiki/Daniel_Webster "Daniel Webster"), but his more important
speeches show careful preparation and his opinions carried weight; the oft-
repeated charge that he refrained from declaring himself on crucial questions
is hardly borne out by scrutiny of his senatorial career. In [February
1827](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_New_York,_1827 "United States
Senate election in New York, 1827"), he was re-elected to the Senate by a
large majority. He became one of the recognized managers of the Jackson
campaign, and his tour of [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"), [the
Carolinas](/wiki/The_Carolinas "The Carolinas"), and
[Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_\(U.S._state\) "Georgia \(U.S. state\)") in the spring
of 1827 won support for Jackson from Crawford as Van Buren sought to
reorganize and unify "the old Republican party" behind Jackson.[70] At the
state level, Jackson's committee chairs would split up the responsibilities
around the state and organize volunteers at the local level. "Hurra Boys"
would plant hickory trees (in honor of Jackson's nickname, "Old Hickory") or
hand out hickory sticks at rallies. In 1828 Van Buren ran for [Governor of New
York](/wiki/Governor_of_New_York "Governor of New York") in an effort to use
his personal popularity to bolster Jackson's chances of carrying New York in
the presidential election. Jackson defeated Adams handily, leading the pro-
Adams _New York American_ to editorialize "Organization is the secret of
victory. By the want of it we have been overthrown."[71] Van Buren won his
election, and resigned from the Senate to start the gubernatorial term, which
began on January 1, 1829.[72]

Van Buren's tenure as New York governor is the second shortest on record.
While his term was short, he did manage to pass the Bank Safety Fund Law (an
early form of deposit insurance) through the Legislature.[73]

## Secretary of
State[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Secretary of State")]

On March 5, 1829, President Jackson appointed Van Buren [Secretary of
State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States Secretary of
State"), an office which probably had been promised him before the 1828
elections, and Van Buren resigned the governorship on March 12.[74] He was
succeeded by his Lieutenant Governor, [Enos T. Throop](/wiki/Enos_T._Throop
"Enos T. Throop"), a member of the Regency.

As Secretary of State, Van Buren sought congeniality with the [Kitchen
Cabinet](/wiki/Kitchen_Cabinet "Kitchen Cabinet"), Jackson's informal
advisers. He sometimes opposed Jackson in the matter of removing political
appointees from office to replace them with Jackson loyalists, but also saw to
the replacement of postmasters in New York with Van Buren loyalists.[75] In
July 1829, [Rutgers College](/wiki/Rutgers_University "Rutgers University")
awarded Van Buren the [honorary degree](/wiki/Honorary_degree "Honorary
degree") of [LL.D.](/wiki/Legum_Doctor "Legum Doctor")[76]

No serious diplomatic crises arose during Van Buren's tenure, but he achieved
several notable successes, such as settling long-standing claims against
France and winning reparations for property that had been seized during the
[Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars"). He reached an
agreement with the British to open trade with the [British West
Indies](/wiki/British_West_Indies "British West Indies") colonies and
concluded a treaty with the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman
Empire") that gained American merchants access to the [Black
Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea"). Items on which he did not achieve success
included settling the [Maine](/wiki/Maine "Maine")-[New
Brunswick](/wiki/New_Brunswick "New Brunswick") boundary dispute with Great
Britain, gaining settlement of the U.S. claim to the [Oregon
Country](/wiki/Oregon_Country "Oregon Country"), concluding a commercial
treaty with [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"), and persuading
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") to sell [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas").[77][78]

Van Buren also advised Jackson informally on matters of domestic policy—in the
controversy over the [Bank of the United
States](/wiki/Second_Bank_of_the_United_States "Second Bank of the United
States"), he sided with Jackson. He also allied with Jackson on the [Indian
Removal Act](/wiki/Indian_Removal_Act "Indian Removal Act").[78][79] After the
breach between Jackson and Calhoun, which culminated with the [Nullification
Crisis](/wiki/Nullification_Crisis "Nullification Crisis"), Van Buren's
position as one of Jackson's primary political supporters and policy advisors
clearly branded him as the most prominent candidate for the vice presidency in
1832, and Jackson's most likely successor in 1836.[80]

### Petticoat
affair[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Petticoat affair")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/62/Floride_Calhoun_nee_Colhoun.jpg)](/wiki/File:Floride_Calhoun_nee_Colhoun.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Floride_Calhoun_nee_Colhoun.jpg "Enlarge")

Mrs Floride Calhoun, a leader of the "petticoats"

Further information: [Petticoat affair](/wiki/Petticoat_affair "Petticoat
affair")

In Jackson's first term, Van Buren won the president's lasting regard by his
courtesies to [Peggy Eaton](/wiki/Peggy_Eaton "Peggy Eaton"), wife of
[Secretary of War](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War "United States
Secretary of War") [John H. Eaton](/wiki/John_H._Eaton "John H. Eaton"), whom
the wives of the cabinet members and others had shunned over the circumstances
surrounding their marriage and her alleged moral failures as a cabinet
wife.[81][82] Led by [Floride Calhoun](/wiki/Floride_Calhoun "Floride
Calhoun"), wife of Vice President Calhoun, these women (the "petticoats")
socially ostracized the Eatons, refused to pay courtesy calls at their home or
receive them as visitors, and denied them invitations to social events.[83]

Because Calhoun was the most visible opponent of the Jackson administration,
Jackson felt that Calhoun and other anti-Jackson officials were fanning the
flames of the Peggy Eaton controversy to gain political leverage.[84] As a
widower, Van Buren was unaffected by the position of the Cabinet wives, and he
supported Jackson's position that criticism of the Eatons would not be
tolerated. By siding with Jackson, Van Buren helped create a counter-coalition
that weakened Calhoun.[85]

The dispute was resolved when Van Buren offered to resign; in April 1831,
Jackson accepted, and took the opportunity to reorganize his cabinet by asking
for the resignations of Cabinet members whose wives were part of the anti-
Eaton coalition.[86] Postmaster General [William T.
Barry](/wiki/William_T._Barry "William T. Barry"), who had sided with Jackson
and Van Buren, was the lone cabinet member to stay,[87] and Eaton eventually
received appointments that took him away from Washington, first as [governor
of Florida Territory](/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Florida "List of Governors of
Florida"), and then as [minister to
Spain](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_Spain "United States Ambassador to
Spain").[88]

## Vice-
Presidency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Vice-Presidency")]

After resigning as Secretary of State, Van Buren remained in office until June
1831, and continued to play a part in Jackson's [Kitchen
Cabinet](/wiki/Kitchen_Cabinet "Kitchen Cabinet").[89] In August 1831 Jackson
gave Van Buren a [recess appointment](/wiki/Recess_appointment "Recess
appointment") as [Minister to the Court of St. James
(Britain)](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_the_United_Kingdom "United States
Ambassador to the United Kingdom") and he arrived in London in September.[90]
He was cordially received, but in February he learned his nomination was
rejected by the Senate on January 25, 1832.[91] The rejection was attributed
to Van Buren's instructions while Secretary of State to [Louis
McLane](/wiki/Louis_McLane "Louis McLane"), the American minister to Britain,
which concerned the opening of the West Indies trade, and repudiated the
foreign policy of Jackson's predecessors, which the Senate claimed was a
breach of decorum.[92] The rejection of Van Buren was essentially the work of
Calhoun, who had opposed Van Buren's confirmation, believing that Van Buren
had attempted to keep him from becoming vice president by making overtures to
[Henry Clay](/wiki/Henry_Clay "Henry Clay") to run on a ticket with William H.
Crawford, Van Buren's preferred candidate for president in 1824.[93] Calhoun
also opposed Van Buren for his role in the Petticoat Affair and his work on
the 1828 tariff. When the vote on Van Buren's nomination was taken, enough
pro-Calhoun Democrats refrained from voting to produce a tie, thus giving
Calhoun, in his role as presiding officer, the ability to cast a vote. He
voted against Van Buren, and so achieved "vengeance" on Van Buren.[94] Calhoun
was elated, convinced that he had ended Van Buren's career. "It will kill him
dead, sir, kill him dead. He will never kick, sir, never kick," Calhoun
exclaimed to a friend within earshot of Missouri Senator [Thomas Hart
Benton](/wiki/Thomas_Hart_Benton_\(senator\) "Thomas Hart Benton
\(senator\)").[95]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Francis_Alexander_-
_Martin_Van_Buren_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Francis_Alexander_-
_Martin_Van_Buren_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)](/wiki/File:Francis_Alexander_-
_Martin_Van_Buren_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Francis_Alexander_-_Martin_Van_Buren_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg
"Enlarge")

A painting of Van Buren by [Francis Alexander](/wiki/Francis_Alexander
"Francis Alexander"), c. 1830–1840

Benton recognized the significance of Calhoun's action, saying "You have
broken a minister and made a vice president."[96] [John
Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler"), then serving as a Senator from
[Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"), also recognized Calhoun's overreach,
writing to a friend that "Van Buren is elevated by the silly thing of
rejecting him."[97] As Benton and Tyler foresaw, Calhoun's move backfired, by
making Van Buren appear the victim of petty politics, thus raising him in both
Jackson's regard and the esteem of others in the Democratic Party. Far from
ending Van Buren's career, Calhoun's action gave greater impetus to Van
Buren's candidacy for vice president.[98]

After a brief tour of Europe, Van Buren reached New York on July 5, 1832. The
May [1832 Democratic National
Convention](/wiki/1832_Democratic_National_Convention "1832 Democratic
National Convention"), the party's first, had nominated him for vice president
on the Jackson ticket.[99] Van Buren's nomination was not as strongly
supported as Jackson's, particularly among southerners who recalled his work
on the tariff in 1828, but he somewhat placated southerners by denying the
right of Congress to abolish slavery in the [District of
Columbia](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") without the consent of
the slave states.[100]

The Jackson-Van Buren ticket won the [election of
1832](/wiki/U.S._presidential_election,_1832 "U.S. presidential election,
1832") by a landslide,[101] and Van Buren took office as Vice President in
March 1833.[102] During his time in office Van Buren continued to be one of
Jackson's primary advisors and confidants, and accompanied Jackson on his tour
of the northeastern United States in 1833.[103] Jackson's confidence in Van
Buren was further demonstrated after Jackson named [Benjamin F.
Butler](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin_Butler_\(lawyer\) "Benjamin Franklin Butler
\(lawyer\)"), Van Buren's political ally and former law partner, to serve as
[Attorney General](/wiki/United_States_Attorney_General "United States
Attorney General"),[104] and [John Forsyth](/wiki/John_Forsyth_\(Georgia\)
"John Forsyth \(Georgia\)"), another Van Buren ally, to serve as Secretary of
State.[105][106]

Van Buren's support of Jackson in the Nullification Crisis and the decision
not to recharter the Second Bank of the United States made him a target of
Jackson's most vocal opponents. Van Buren was threatened with violence,
including explicit comments from Senator [George
Poindexter](/wiki/George_Poindexter "George Poindexter") of Mississippi, which
prompted Van Buren to carry pistols for self-defense.[107] However he also
demonstrated both the willingness and the ability to work with his opponents,
cooperating with Clay and Calhoun (now a Senator) to pass the compromise
[Tariff of 1833](/wiki/Tariff_of_1833 "Tariff of 1833"), which helped end the
Nullification Crisis.[108][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]

During one contentious debate on the bank issue, Van Buren presided over the
Senate as Clay spoke passionately about the harm he believed Jackson's bank
policy would cause. Directing his remarks to Van Buren, Clay asked
rhetorically whether Van Buren would approach Jackson and persuade him to
change his mind. After Clay concluded, observers wondered how Van Buren would
react. Van Buren's response was to descend from the rostrum and ask Clay if he
could borrow a pinch of [snuff](/wiki/Snuff_\(tobacco\) "Snuff \(tobacco\)").
Caught off guard, Clay reflexively handed over his [snuff box](/wiki/Snuff_box
"Snuff box"). Van Buren took a pinch, bowed to Clay, and left the chamber,
both deflating the effect of Clay's remarks and preventing tension from
escalating, as would have happened if Van Buren had attempted to reply
directly.[109]

## Presidential election of
1836[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Presidential election of 1836")]

Main article: [United States presidential election,
1836](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1836 "United States
presidential election, 1836")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/ElectoralCollege1836.svg/220px-
ElectoralCollege1836.svg.png)](/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1836.svg)

[](/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1836.svg "Enlarge")

1836 electoral vote results

Jackson, not running in 1836, was determined to make Van Buren his successor
in order to continue the Jackson administration's policies.[110] This
conclusion on Jackson's part soon became public. When the [Democratic
Convention](/wiki/1835_Democratic_National_Convention "1835 Democratic
National Convention") met in [Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore"),
[Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland") in May, 1835, 18 months before the
election, the delegates nominated Van Buren [unanimously](/wiki/Unanimity
"Unanimity").[111] Two names were put forward for the vice-presidential
nomination: Representative [Richard M. Johnson](/wiki/Richard_M._Johnson
"Richard M. Johnson") of Kentucky, and former senator [William Cabell
Rives](/wiki/William_Cabell_Rives "William Cabell Rives") of Virginia.
Southern Democrats, and Van Buren himself, strongly preferred Rives. Jackson,
on the other hand, strongly preferred Johnson. Again, Jackson's considerable
influence prevailed, however, Johnson received the required two-thirds vote
only after New York Senator [Silas Wright](/wiki/Silas_Wright "Silas Wright")
prevailed upon non-delegate Edward Rucker to cast the 15 votes of the absent
Tennessee delegation in his favor.[112][111]

On the issue of slavery, Van Buren moved to obtain the support of southerners
by assuring them that he opposed abolitionism and supported the maintaining of
slavery in states where it had already existed.[113] Regarding the national
bank, Van Buren made clear that he opposed rechartering a [national
bank](/wiki/Second_Bank_of_the_United_States "Second Bank of the United
States").[114] To demonstrate [consistency](/wiki/Good_faith "Good faith")
regarding his opinions on slavery, Van Buren cast the tie-breaking Senate vote
in favor of [engrossing](/wiki/Enrolled_bill "Enrolled bill") a bill to
subject [abolitionist](/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism
in the United States") mail to state laws, thus ensuring that its circulation
would be prohibited in the South.[115]

Martin Van Buren's competitors in the [election of
1836](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1836 "United States
presidential election, 1836") were three members of the newly established
[Whig Party](/wiki/Whig_Party_\(United_States\) "Whig Party \(United
States\)"). Still a loose [coalition](/wiki/Coalition "Coalition") bound by
mutual opposition to Jackson's anti-bank policies but lacking the party unity
or organizational strength to field a single ticket or define a coherent
platform,[112] the Whigs ran several regional candidates in hopes of sending
the election to the House of Representatives, where each state delegation
would have one vote and the Whigs would stand a better chance of winning.[116]
They were: [Hugh White](/wiki/Hugh_Lawson_White "Hugh Lawson White") of
Tennessee, [Daniel Webster](/wiki/Daniel_Webster "Daniel Webster") of
Massachusetts, and [William Henry Harrison](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison
"William Henry Harrison") of Indiana. Besides endorsing internal improvements
and a national bank, the Whigs tried to tie Democrats to abolitionism and
sectional tension, and attacked Jackson for "acts of aggression and usurpation
of power."[117]

The Whigs nominated New York [Anti-Mason](/wiki/Anti-Masonic_Party "Anti-
Masonic Party") [Francis Granger](/wiki/Francis_Granger "Francis Granger") and
former Democrat [John Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler") of Virginia for
vice president.[112] Richard Johnson, Van Buren's running mate, was a hero of
the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"), and claimed to have killed
[Tecumseh](/wiki/Tecumseh "Tecumseh") at the [Battle of the
Thames](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Thames "Battle of the Thames"). Since Harrison was
campaigning for president as the "hero of
[Tippecanoe](/wiki/Battle_of_Tippecanoe "Battle of Tippecanoe")," Johnson's
friends countered with:

> Rumpsey, dumpsey, rumpsey dumpsey,  
>  Colonel Johnson killed Tecumseh![118]

Van Buren won the election with 764,198 popular votes, only 50.9 percent of
the total, and 170 [electoral votes](/wiki/Electoral_College_\(United_States\)
"Electoral College \(United States\)"). Harrison led the Whigs with 73
electoral votes, White receiving 26 and Webster 14. Willie P. Mangum of South
Carolina received his state’s 11 electoral votes.[117] Van Buren's victory
resulted from a combination of his own attractive political and personal
qualities, Jackson's popularity and endorsement, the organizational power of
the Democratic party, and the inability of the Whig Party—at this point—to
muster an effective candidate and campaign.[119] Johnson, however, received
only 147 electoral votes, 70 more than his closest contender, Francis Granger,
but one less than the number required to elect. Virginia's electors had
remained loyal to Van Buren, who carried the state by a close margin,[112] but
instead, they all [refused to vote for](/wiki/Faithless_elector "Faithless
elector") Johnson.[120]

Van Buren was the first president to be born after the [United States
Declaration of Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence
"United States Declaration of Independence") from the [Kingdom of Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain").

On February 8, 1837, the U.S. Senate convened, and in accordance with the
[Twelfth Amendment](/wiki/Twelfth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution") chose the vice
president from the two top electoral vote recipients, Johnson, and Granger.
Johnson won the contingent vote, 33-17, and became the nation's ninth vice
president.[121]

## Presidency
1837–1841[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Presidency 1837–1841")]

[![BEP engraved portrait of Van Buren as
President](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/VAN_BUREN%2C_Martin-
President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg/350px-VAN_BUREN%2C_Martin-
President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:VAN_BUREN,_Martin-
President_\(BEP_engraved_portrait\).jpg)

[File:VAN BUREN, Martin-President (BEP engraved
portrait).jpg](/wiki/File:VAN_BUREN,_Martin-
President_\(BEP_engraved_portrait\).jpg "File:VAN BUREN, Martin-President
\(BEP engraved portrait\).jpg")

[BEP](/wiki/Bureau_of_Engraving_and_Printing "Bureau of Engraving and
Printing") engraved portrait of Van Buren as President

Main article: [Presidency of Martin Van
Buren](/wiki/Presidency_of_Martin_Van_Buren "Presidency of Martin Van Buren")

### White House
hostess[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: White House hostess")]

For the first half of his presidency, Van Buren, who had been a widower for
many years, did not have a specific person fill the role of White House
hostess at administration social events, but tried to assume such duties
himself. When his eldest son [Abraham Van Buren](/wiki/Abraham_Van_Buren
"Abraham Van Buren") married [Angelica
Singleton](/wiki/Angelica_Singleton_Van_Buren "Angelica Singleton Van Buren")
in 1838, he quickly acted to install his daughter-in-law as his hostess. She
solicited the advice of her distant relative, [Dolley
Madison](/wiki/Dolley_Madison "Dolley Madison"),[122] who had moved back to
Washington after her [husband's](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison")
death,[123] and soon the president's parties livened up. After the 1839 New
Year's Eve reception, the _Boston Post_ raved: "[Angelica Van Buren is a] lady
of rare accomplishments, very modest yet perfectly easy and graceful in her
manners and free and vivacious in her conversation ... universally
admired."[122]

As the nation endured a deep [economic depression](/wiki/Economic_depression
"Economic depression"), Angelica van Buren's receiving style at receptions was
influenced by her heavy reading on European court life (and her naive delight
in being received as the _Queen of the United States_ when she visited the
royal courts of England and France after her marriage). Newspaper coverage of
this, in addition to the claim that she intended to re-landscape the [White
House grounds](/wiki/South_Lawn_\(White_House\) "South Lawn \(White House\)")
to resemble the royal gardens of Europe, was used in a political attack on her
father-in-law by a Pennsylvania Whig Congressman [Charles
Ogle](/wiki/Charles_Ogle_\(politician\) "Charles Ogle \(politician\)"). He
referred obliquely to her as part of the presidential "household" in his
famous [Gold Spoon Oration](/wiki/Gold_Spoon_Oration "Gold Spoon Oration").
The attack was delivered in Congress and the depiction of the President as
living a royal lifestyle was a primary factor in his defeat for re-
election.[124]

### Panic of
1837[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Panic of 1837")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Jackson_and_Van_Buren%2C_1837.jpg/220px-
Jackson_and_Van_Buren%2C_1837.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jackson_and_Van_Buren,_1837.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jackson_and_Van_Buren,_1837.jpg "Enlarge")

_**The modern balaam and his ass**_ , an 1837 caricature placing the blame for
the Panic of 1837 and the perilous state of the banking system on outgoing
President Andrew Jackson, shown riding a donkey, while President Martin Van
Buren comments approvingly.

When Van Buren entered office, the nation's economic health had taken a turn
for the worse and the prosperity of the early 1830s was over. Two months into
his presidency, on May 10, 1837, some important state banks in New York,
running out of hard currency reserves, refused to convert paper money into
gold or silver, and other financial institutions throughout the nation quickly
followed suit. This [financial crisis](/wiki/Financial_crisis "Financial
crisis") would become known as the [Panic of 1837](/wiki/Panic_of_1837 "Panic
of 1837").[125] The Panic was followed by a five-year
[depression](/wiki/Depression_\(economics\) "Depression \(economics\)") in
which banks failed and [unemployment](/wiki/Unemployment "Unemployment")
reached record highs.[126]

Van Buren blamed the economic collapse on greedy American and foreign business
and financial institutions, as well as the over-extension of credit by U.S.
banks. Whig leaders in Congress blamed the Democrats, along with Andrew
Jackson's economic policies,[125] specifically his 1836 [Specie
Circular](/wiki/Specie_Circular "Specie Circular"). Cries of "rescind the
circular!" went up and former President Jackson sent word to Van Buren asking
him not to rescind the order, believing that it had to be given enough time to
work. Others, like [Nicholas Biddle](/wiki/Nicholas_Biddle_\(banker\)
"Nicholas Biddle \(banker\)"), believed that Jackson's [dismantling of the
Bank of the United States](/wiki/Bank_War#Jackson's_dismantling_of_the_BUS
"Bank War") was directly responsible for the irresponsible creation of paper
money by the state banks which had precipitated this panic.[127]

To deal with the crisis, the Whigs proposed rechartering the [national
bank](/wiki/History_of_central_banking_in_the_United_States "History of
central banking in the United States"). The president countered by proposing
the establishment of an [independent U.S. treasury](/wiki/Independent_Treasury
"Independent Treasury"), which would take the politics out of the nation's
money supply; the government would hold all of its money balances in the form
of [gold or silver](/wiki/Hard_money_\(policy\) "Hard money \(policy\)") and
would be restricted from printing [paper money](/wiki/Banknote "Banknote") at
will, a measure designed to prevent [inflation](/wiki/Inflation
"Inflation").[128] Van Buren announced his proposal in September 1837;[125]
but that was too much for state banking interests, and an alliance of
conservative Democrats and Whigs prevented it from becoming law until
1840.[129] The independent treasury lasted only one year—the Whigs, who won a
congressional majority and the presidency in the 1840 elections, promptly
repealed the law.[130]

By the time Congress finally acted, the nation's economy had been mired in a
depression for nearly four years; the problems would continue into the early
1840s. More important for Van Buren's immediate future, the depression would
be a major issue in his upcoming re-election campaign.[125]

### Indian
removals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Indian removals")]

In 1838, Van Buren directed General [Winfield Scott](/wiki/Winfield_Scott
"Winfield Scott") to forcibly institute the [removal](/wiki/Indian_removal
"Indian removal") of all those [Cherokee](/wiki/Cherokee "Cherokee") who had
not complied with the 1835 [Treaty of New Echota](/wiki/Treaty_of_New_Echota
"Treaty of New Echota")—by departing from the [Southeastern United
States](/wiki/Southeastern_United_States "Southeastern United States") and
moving west (to present day [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma")).[131] The
Cherokee were herded violently into internment camps, where they were kept for
the summer of 1838. The actual transportation west was delayed by intense heat
and drought, but in the fall, the Cherokee reluctantly agreed to transport
themselves west.[132][133] During the Cherokee removal, part of the [Trail of
Tears](/wiki/Trail_of_Tears "Trail of Tears"), some 20,000 people were
involuntarily relocated.[7]

In the course of Van Buren's presidency the federal government negotiated 19
treaties with [Indian nations](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States
"Native Americans in the United States"). The administration also contended
with the Seminole in Florida, who engaged the
[army](/wiki/Regular_Army_\(United_States\) "Regular Army \(United States\)")
in a seven-year battle.[134] Known as the [Second Seminole
War](/wiki/Second_Seminole_War "Second Seminole War"), the battle began in
1835 during Jackson's presidency. Fighting was not resolved until 1842, after
Van Buren had left office.[135] It is regarded as the longest and most costly
of the nation's [Indian conflicts](/wiki/American_Indian_Wars "American Indian
Wars").[136][137]

### Mormons[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Mormons")]

In 1839, [Joseph Smith, Jr.](/wiki/Joseph_Smith "Joseph Smith"), the founder
of the [Latter Day Saint movement](/wiki/Latter_Day_Saint_movement "Latter Day
Saint movement"), visited Van Buren to plead for the U.S. to help roughly
20,000 Mormon settlers of [Independence,
Missouri](/wiki/Independence,_Missouri "Independence, Missouri") (who were
forced from the state during the [1838 Mormon War](/wiki/Mormon_War_\(1838\)
"Mormon War \(1838\)").) The Governor of Missouri, [Lilburn
Boggs](/wiki/Lilburn_Boggs "Lilburn Boggs"), had issued [an executive
order](/wiki/Missouri_Executive_Order_44 "Missouri Executive Order 44") on
October 27, 1838, known as the "Extermination Order". It authorized troops to
use force against Mormons to "exterminate or drive [them] from the
state".[138][139] In 1839, after moving to Illinois, Smith and his party
appealed to members of Congress and to President Van Buren to intercede for
the Mormons. According to Smith's grandnephew, Van Buren said to Smith, "Your
cause is just, but I can do nothing for you; if I take up for you I shall lose
the vote of Missouri".[140][141]

### Texas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Texas")]

In a bold step, Van Buren reversed Andrew Jackson's policies and sought peace
at home, as well as abroad. Instead of settling a financial dispute between
American citizens and the Mexican government by force, Van Buren wanted to
seek a diplomatic solution. In an action that upset political leaders of the
pro-slavery states, in August 1837, Van Buren denied [Texas](/wiki/Texas
"Texas")' formal request to join the United States, partly to prevent the
upset of the slave state/free state balance in the [Missouri
Compromise](/wiki/Missouri_Compromise "Missouri Compromise"), and partly
because he hoped to avoid a possible war with Mexico over Texas
annexation.[142][143]

### British North
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: British North America")]

British subjects in [Lower Canada](/wiki/Lower_Canada "Lower Canada") (now
Quebec) and [Upper Canada](/wiki/Upper_Canada "Upper Canada") (now Ontario)
rose in [rebellion](/wiki/Rebellion "Rebellion") in
[1837](/wiki/Lower_Canada_Rebellion "Lower Canada Rebellion") and
[1838](/wiki/Upper_Canada_Rebellion "Upper Canada Rebellion") respectively,
protesting their lack of [responsible government](/wiki/Responsible_government
"Responsible government"). The rebellion in Upper Canada was led by [William
Lyon Mackenzie](/wiki/William_Lyon_Mackenzie "William Lyon Mackenzie") and
[Charles Duncombe](/wiki/Charles_Duncombe_\(Upper_Canada_Rebellion\) "Charles
Duncombe \(Upper Canada Rebellion\)").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/DENT%281881%29_1.213_DESTRUCTION_OF_THE_CAROLINE.jpg/300px-
DENT%281881%29_1.213_DESTRUCTION_OF_THE_CAROLINE.jpg)](/wiki/File:DENT\(1881\)_1.213_DESTRUCTION_OF_THE_CAROLINE.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DENT\(1881\)_1.213_DESTRUCTION_OF_THE_CAROLINE.jpg "Enlarge")

"Destruction of the _Caroline_ ", illustration by John Charles Dent (1881)

While the initial insurrection in Upper Canada ended quickly (following the
December 7 [Battle of Montgomery's
Tavern](/wiki/Battle_of_Montgomery%27s_Tavern "Battle of Montgomery's
Tavern")), many of the rebels fled across the [Niagara
River](/wiki/Niagara_River "Niagara River") into New York, where Mackenzie
began recruiting volunteers in [Buffalo](/wiki/Buffalo,_New_York "Buffalo, New
York").[144] On December 13, Mackenzie declared establishment of the [Republic
of Canada](/wiki/Republic_of_Canada "Republic of Canada") and put into motion
a plan whereby volunteers would invade Upper Canada from [Navy
Island](/wiki/Navy_Island "Navy Island") on the Canadian side of the Niagara
River. Several hundred volunteers procured the steamboat
_[Caroline](/wiki/Caroline_affair "Caroline affair")_ to deliver supplies and
arms to Navy Island from [Fort Schlosser](/wiki/Fort_Schlosser "Fort
Schlosser").[144] To deter an imminent invasion, British forces crossed to the
American bank of the river, where they burned and sank the ship. When an
American was killed and others wounded,[145] considerable sentiment arose
within the United States to declare war, and a British ship was burned in
revenge.[146] Soon afterward, Mackenzie’s "republic" collapsed, and the rebels
withdrew into the U.S.; the initial uprising in Lower Canada by then collapsed
as well.

Van Buren, looking to avoid a war with Great Britain, sent General Winfield
Scott to the [border](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border "Canada–United
States border") with broad discretionary powers for its protection and its
peace.[147] Scott impressed upon American citizens the need for a peaceful
resolution to the crisis, and made it clear that the U.S. government would not
support adventuresome Americans attacking the British. Also, in early January
1838, the president proclaimed U.S. neutrality with regard to the Canadian
independence issue, a declaration which Congress endorsed by passing a
neutrality law discouraging the participation of American citizens in foreign
conflicts.[146]

Simultaneously Charles Duncombe and Robert Nelson helped foment a largely
American militia, the [Hunters' Lodge](/wiki/Hunters%27_Lodges "Hunters'
Lodges")/[Frères chasseurs](/wiki/Fr%C3%A8res_chasseurs "Frères chasseurs"),
which carried out several attacks in Upper Canada between December 1837 and
December 1838, collectively known as the [Patriot War](/wiki/Patriot_War
"Patriot War").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The administration followed through on its
enforcement of the Neutrality Act, encouraged the prosecution of filibusters,
and actively deterred U.S. citizens from subversive activities abroad. In the
long term, the Patriot War contributed to the construction of healthy
[Anglo–American](/wiki/Special_relationship "Special relationship") and
[U.S.–Canadian](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Canada–United
States relations") relationships in the 20th century; it also led, more
immediately, to a backlash among citizens against the overreach of federal
authority,[148] which hurt congressional Democrats in the 1838 midterm
elections.

Another crisis surfaced in late 1838, in the disputed territory on the
[Maine](/wiki/Maine "Maine")–[New Brunswick](/wiki/New_Brunswick "New
Brunswick") frontier, where Americans were settling on disputed land claimed
by the United States and Great Britain. Both American and New Brunswick
[lumberjacks](/wiki/Lumberjack "Lumberjack") cut timber in the disputed
territory during the winter of 1838–39. On December 29, New Brunswick
lumbermen were spotted cutting down trees on an American’s estate near the
[Aroostook River](/wiki/Aroostook_River "Aroostook River").[146] American
woodcutters rushed to stand guard. A shouting match, known as the [Battle of
Caribou](/wiki/Battle_of_Caribou "Battle of Caribou"), ensued.

Tensions quickly boiled over into a near war with both Maine and New Brunswick
arresting each other's citizens. The crisis seemed ready to turn into an armed
conflict.[149] British troops began to gather on the [Saint John
River](/wiki/St._John_River_\(Bay_of_Fundy\) "St. John River \(Bay of
Fundy\)"). The American press clamored for war; “Maine and her soil, or
BLOOD!” screamed one editorial. “Let the sword be drawn and the scabbard
thrown away!” Congress authorized 50,000 troops and a $10 million budget.[150]

To settle the crisis, Van Buren met with the British minister to the United
States. They agreed to resolve the border issue diplomatically. Van Buren also
sent General Scott to the northern border area to show military resolve and
more importantly to lower the tensions. Scott successfully convinced all sides
to submit the border issue to arbitration. The dispute was put to rest a few
years later, with the signing of the 1842 [Webster–Ashburton
Treaty](/wiki/Webster%E2%80%93Ashburton_Treaty "Webster–Ashburton
Treaty").[146]

### _United States v. The
Amistad_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: United States v. The Amistad")]

The _[Amistad](/wiki/United_States_v._The_Amistad "United States v. The
Amistad")_ case was a [freedom suit](/wiki/Freedom_suit "Freedom suit") that
involved international issues and parties, as well as United States law,
resulting from the rebellion of Africans on board the Spanish
[schooner](/wiki/Schooner "Schooner") _[La Amistad](/wiki/La_Amistad "La
Amistad")_ in 1839,.[151] The Van Buren administration supported the [Spanish
government's](/wiki/Government_of_Spain "Government of Spain") demand that the
ship and its cargo (including the Africans) be turned over to them.[152] When
a Federal District Court judge ruled that the Africans were legally free and
should be transported home, the administration appealed the case to the
Supreme Court.

In February 1840, former President (and sitting U.S. Representative from
Massachusetts) [John Quincy Adams](/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams "John Quincy
Adams") argued passionately for the Africans' right to freedom. Attorney
General [Henry D. Gilpin](/wiki/Henry_D._Gilpin "Henry D. Gilpin") presented
the government’s case. In March 1841, the Supreme Court issued its final
verdict: the _Amistad_ Africans were free people and should be allowed to
return home.[153] The unique nature of the case, people of color testifying in
federal court, and being represented by prominent lawyers, heightened public
interest in the saga, as did the participation of former president Adams. The
Amistad case drew attention to the personal tragedies of slavery and attracted
new support for the growing abolition movement in the North. It also
transformed the courts into the principal forum for a national debate on the
legal foundations of slavery.[154]
