Martin Van Buren announced his intention "to follow in the footsteps of his
illustrious predecessor", and retained all but one of Jackson's cabinet.

### Judicial
appointments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Judicial appointments")]

Main article: [Martin Van Buren judicial
appointments](/wiki/Martin_Van_Buren_judicial_appointments "Martin Van Buren
judicial appointments")

Van Buren appointed two [Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States
"Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States"):[155]

  * [John McKinley](/wiki/John_McKinley "John McKinley") – confirmed September 25, 1837
  * [Peter Vivian Daniel](/wiki/Peter_Vivian_Daniel "Peter Vivian Daniel") – confirmed March 2, 1841

Van Buren also appointed eight other federal judges, all to [United States
district courts](/wiki/United_States_district_court "United States district
court").[156]

### Midterm elections of
1838[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Midterm elections of 1838")]

The Panic of 1837 loomed large over the [1838 election
cycle](/wiki/United_States_elections,_1838 "United States elections, 1838"),
as the carryover effects of the economic downturn led to Whig gains in both
the U.S. House and Senate. Also, while the Democratic Party retained a
majority in both chambers,[157][158] a split among House Democrats led to Whig
Congressman [Robert M. T. Hunter](/wiki/Robert_M._T._Hunter "Robert M. T.
Hunter") being elected [Speaker of the
House](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives "Speaker of
the United States House of Representatives") for the [26th
Congress](/wiki/26th_United_States_Congress "26th United States
Congress").[159] Likewise, state elections in 1837 and 1838 were disastrous
for the Democrats,[160] and the partial economic recovery in 1838 was offset
by a second commercial crisis later that year.[161]

### Presidential election of
1840[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Presidential election of 1840")]

Main article: [United States presidential election,
1840](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1840 "United States
presidential election, 1840")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/ElectoralCollege1840.svg/220px-
ElectoralCollege1840.svg.png)](/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1840.svg)

[](/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1840.svg "Enlarge")

1840 electoral vote results

Van Buren easily won renomination for a second term at the [1840 Democratic
National Convention](/wiki/1840_Democratic_National_Convention "1840
Democratic National Convention"), but he and his party faced a difficult
[election in 1840](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1840 "United
States presidential election, 1840"). Van Buren's presidency had been
problematic, with the U.S. economy mired in a severe downturn; also of concern
were several divisive issues—slavery, western expansion, and tensions with
Great Britain—that provided opportunities for Van Buren's political opponents,
and even some fellow Democrats to criticize him.[119] Although Van Buren's
renomination was never in doubt, Democratic strategists began to question the
wisdom of keeping Johnson on the ticket. Even former president Jackson
conceded that Johnson was a liability and insisted on former House Speaker
[James K. Polk](/wiki/James_K._Polk "James K. Polk") of Tennessee as Van
Buren's new running mate. With William Henry Harrison, Johnson's former
commander and comrade-in-arms and the "Hero of Tippecanoe," emerging as a
likely [Whig](/wiki/Whig_Party_\(United_States\) "Whig Party \(United
States\)") presidential contender, Van Buren was reluctant to drop the
Democrats' own hero from the ticket.[112] The convention decided to allow
state Democratic Party leaders to select the vice-presidential candidates for
their states.[162]

The Whigs did select Harrison as their nominee, and presented him to the
nation as the antithesis of the president, whom they derided as ineffective,
corrupt, and effete.[119] Van Buren was blamed for the hard economic times,
and ridiculed as "Martin Van Ruin".[163] Van Buren's rather elegant personal
style was also an easy target for Whig attacks, such as the [Gold Spoon
Oration](/wiki/Gold_Spoon_Oration "Gold Spoon Oration").[164]

Van Buren remained optimistic about his chances for reelection until October
1840, by which time it became unlikely that he would defeat Harrison. An
astonishing 80 percent of eligible voters went to the polls on election
day.[119] Harrison won by a popular vote of 1,275,612 to 1,130,033, and an
electoral vote margin of 234 to 60.[117] Additionally, Whigs won majorities
for the first time in both the U.S. House and the Senate.[112]

A [linguistic](/wiki/Linguistic "Linguistic") legacy of the 1840 campaign was
attributed to Van Buren himself—the expression "[OK](/wiki/OK "OK")."[165]
Although some language experts attribute OK to other proposed origins,
including words from the [Choctaw](/wiki/Choctaw_language "Choctaw language")
or [Wolof](/wiki/Wolof_language "Wolof language") languages,[165][166] and
others to an abbreviation of "oll korrect," misspellings attributed to Andrew
Jackson, the prevailing opinion is that it derives from "**O** ld **K**
inderhook," one of the many nicknames for Van Buren.[165][167] The first
recorded use of "OK" in the sense of approval dates back to 1839 when a
newspaper referred to a Democratic meeting of "the roarers, the butt-enders,
ringtails and OKs," adding, "the allusion was probably to those who put their
OK on the nomination of Van Buren."[165]

## Election of
1844[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Election of 1844")]

On the expiration of his term, Van Buren returned to his estate,
[Lindenwald](/wiki/Lindenwald "Lindenwald") in Kinderhook, where he planned
his return to the White House. He seemed likely to be nominated by the
Democrats in 1844, but in April of that year a Van Buren letter to [William H.
Hammett](/wiki/William_H._Hammett "William H. Hammett") was made public.[168]
In it, Van Buren opposed the immediate annexation of [Texas](/wiki/Texas
"Texas"), but said that he would support annexation once the state of war
between Texas and [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") was resolved.[169] President
[John Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler") had pursued the annexation of
Texas as his chief foreign policy goal, and many Democrats, particularly in
the South, were anxious to quickly complete the annexation of Texas.[170]

Van Buren's opposition to immediate annexation cost him the support of pro-
slavery Democrats; he began the [Democratic National
Convention](/wiki/1844_Democratic_National_Convention "1844 Democratic
National Convention") with a majority of the delegates, but with no southern
support he could not reach the two-thirds threshold required for
nomination.[171] He won 146 of the 266 votes on the first presidential ballot,
with only 12 of his votes coming from Southern states.[170] Van Buren's name
was withdrawn after eight ballots, and a [dark horse](/wiki/Dark_horse "Dark
horse"), [James K. Polk](/wiki/James_K._Polk "James K. Polk"), received the
nomination and went on to win the [1844 presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1844 "United States
presidential election, 1844").[172] After taking office, Polk used [George
Bancroft](/wiki/George_Bancroft "George Bancroft") as an intermediary to offer
Van Buren the ambassadorship to London.[173] Van Buren declined, partly
because he was upset with Polk over the treatment the Van Buren delegates had
received at the 1844 convention, and partly because he was content in his
retirement.[174]

## Later
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Later life")]

[![A three-quarters length painted portrait of a balding man with gray hair,
standing with his right hand grasping a bundle of papers lying on a
table](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Mvanburen.jpeg/170px-
Mvanburen.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Mvanburen.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Mvanburen.jpeg "Enlarge")

1858 portrait by [GPA Healy](/wiki/George_Peter_Alexander_Healy "George Peter
Alexander Healy"), on display at the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White
House")

Van Buren had resisted the slightest interference with the institution of
slavery in the states where it existed.[175] After leaving the White House,
Van Buren grew increasingly opposed to slavery, and his earlier views about
its constitutional standing gave way over time to acceptance of anti-slavery
positions including opposing slavery's expansion into newly organized western
states.[176] In [1848](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1848 "United
States presidential election, 1848"), he was nominated for president by two
minor parties, first by the "[Barnburner](/wiki/Barnburner "Barnburner")"
faction of the Democratic Party in New York, then by the [Free Soil
Party](/wiki/Free_Soil_Party "Free Soil Party"), with whom the "Barnburners"
coalesced. The Barnburners and Free Soilers opposed Democratic nominee [Lewis
Cass](/wiki/Lewis_Cass "Lewis Cass"), who opposed the [Wilmot
Proviso](/wiki/Wilmot_Proviso "Wilmot Proviso") and was otherwise seen as
friendly to slavery.[177] In addition, Van Buren, who had been denied the 1844
nomination in part due to the efforts of Cass supporters, may have run in
order to exact a measure of revenge by denying Cass the presidency.[178] Van
Buren won no electoral votes, but finished second to Whig nominee [Zachary
Taylor](/wiki/Zachary_Taylor "Zachary Taylor") in New York, taking enough
votes from Cass to give the state—and perhaps the election—to Taylor.[179]

[![Half-length photographic portrait of an elderly, balding man dressed in a
dark coat, vest and
cravat](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Martin_Van_Buren_daguerreotype-
restored.jpg/170px-Martin_Van_Buren_daguerreotype-
restored.jpg)](/wiki/File:Martin_Van_Buren_daguerreotype-restored.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Martin_Van_Buren_daguerreotype-restored.jpg "Enlarge")

[Daguerreotype](/wiki/Daguerreotype "Daguerreotype") of Martin Van Buren,
circa 1855

Unlike many anti-slavery Democrats of the 1840s and 1850s, who later joined
the [Republican Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican
Party \(United States\)"), Van Buren and most of his followers remained in the
Democratic fold. Those followers include his son [John Van
Buren](/wiki/John_Van_Buren "John Van Buren") and [Samuel J.
Tilden](/wiki/Samuel_J._Tilden "Samuel J. Tilden"), who later served as
Governor of New York and was the Democratic nominee for [President in
1876](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1876 "United States
presidential election, 1876").[180][181] Van Buren supported [Franklin
Pierce](/wiki/Franklin_Pierce "Franklin Pierce") for President in 1852, and
[James Buchanan](/wiki/James_Buchanan "James Buchanan") in 1856, though he
later opposed the Buchanan administration's efforts to accommodate the
southern states when they threatened secession.[182][183]

[In the election of 1860](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1860
"United States presidential election, 1860"), he supported [Stephen A.
Douglas](/wiki/Stephen_A._Douglas "Stephen A. Douglas"), the candidate of
northern Democrats, and helped create a [fusion ticket](/wiki/Electoral_fusion
"Electoral fusion") in New York of Democratic
[electors](/wiki/Electoral_College_\(United_States\) "Electoral College
\(United States\)") pledged to both Douglas and [John C.
Breckinridge](/wiki/John_C._Breckinridge "John C. Breckinridge"), but [Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") carried New York and every
northern state except [New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey").[184] Once
the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") began,
Van Buren made public his support for the
[Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American Civil War\)"),
and supported [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln")'s
efforts to prevent the southern states from seceding.[185] In April 1861,
former President Pierce wrote to the other living former Presidents and asked
them to consider meeting in order to use their stature and influence to
propose a negotiated end to the war. Pierce asked Van Buren to use his role as
the senior living ex-President to issue a formal call. Van Buren's reply
suggested that Buchanan should be the one to call the meeting, since he was
the former President who had served most recently, or that Pierce should issue
the call himself if he strongly believed in the merit of his proposal. Neither
Buchanan nor Pierce was willing to make Pierce's proposal public, and nothing
more resulted from it.[186]

Van Buren's health began to fail later in 1861, and he was bedridden with
pneumonia during the fall and winter of 1861–62.[187] He did not recover, and
died of bronchial [asthma](/wiki/Asthma "Asthma") and [heart
failure](/wiki/Heart_failure "Heart failure") at his Lindenwald estate in
Kinderhook at 2:00 a.m. on July 24, 1862, at the age of 79.[188] He is buried
in the [Kinderhook Reformed Dutch
Church](/wiki/Reformed_Dutch_Church_\(Kinderhook,_New_York\) "Reformed Dutch
Church \(Kinderhook, New York\)") Cemetery, as are his wife Hannah, his
parents, and his son Martin Van Buren, Jr.[189]

He is the only U.S. president to have been alive during both the U.S.
Revolutionary War and the U.S. Civil War. As of 2017, he is the most recent
Democrat elected to succeed an incumbent Democratic president who had served
two presidential terms.[190]

## Memorials and popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Martin_Van_Buren&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Memorials and popular culture")]

Main article: [List of memorials to Martin Van
Buren](/wiki/List_of_memorials_to_Martin_Van_Buren "List of memorials to
Martin Van Buren")

Van Buren's home in Kinderhook, New York, which he called Lindenwald, is now
the [Martin Van Buren National Historic
Site](/wiki/Martin_Van_Buren_National_Historic_Site "Martin Van Buren National
Historic Site").[191] Counties are named for Van Buren in
[Michigan](/wiki/Van_Buren_County,_Michigan "Van Buren County, Michigan"),
[Iowa](/wiki/Van_Buren_County,_Iowa "Van Buren County, Iowa"),
[Arkansas](/wiki/Van_Buren_County,_Arkansas "Van Buren County, Arkansas"), and
[Tennessee](/wiki/Van_Buren_County,_Tennessee "Van Buren County,
Tennessee").[192] [A mountain](/wiki/Mount_Van_Buren "Mount Van Buren"), [a
ship](/wiki/USS_Van_Buren_\(1839\) "USS Van Buren \(1839\)"), three state
parks and numerous towns were named after him.

During the [1988 presidential
campaign](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1988 "United States
presidential election, 1988"), [George H. W. Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush
"George H. W. Bush"), a [Yale University](/wiki/Yale_University "Yale
University") graduate and member of the [Skull and
Bones](/wiki/Skull_and_Bones "Skull and Bones") secret society, was attempting
to become the first incumbent Vice President to win election to the presidency
since Van Buren. In the comic strip _[Doonesbury](/wiki/Doonesbury
"Doonesbury")_ artist [Garry Trudeau](/wiki/Garry_Trudeau "Garry Trudeau")
depicted members of Skull and Bones as attempting to rob Van Buren's grave,
apparently intending to use the relics in a ritual that would aid Bush in the
election.[193][194]

On the television show _[Seinfeld](/wiki/Seinfeld "Seinfeld")_ , the episode
"[The Van Buren Boys](/wiki/The_Van_Buren_Boys "The Van Buren Boys")" is about
a fictional [street gang](/wiki/Street_gang "Street gang") that admires Van
Buren and bases its rituals and symbols on him, including the hand sign of
eight fingers pointing up. Eight fingers signifies Van Buren, the eighth
President.[195]

Van Buren is portrayed by [Nigel Hawthorne](/wiki/Nigel_Hawthorne "Nigel
Hawthorne") in the [1997](/wiki/1997_in_film "1997 in film") film
[_Amistad_](/wiki/Amistad_\(film\) "Amistad \(film\)"). The film depicts the
controversy and legal battle surrounding the status of slaves who in 1839
rebelled against their transporters on _[La Amistad](/wiki/La_Amistad "La
Amistad")_ slave ship.[196]
